We have been told that they propose to apply the proceeds of that sale to up-grading the activities of the Irish National Petroleum Corporation at Whitegate. At the same time they are asking the INPC to undertake a £2 million per month loss. If one is to up-grade a facility and ask a company to behave commercially, but then ask them to conspire effectively with the Government to defeat the apparent outcome of market forces for a political end, then by a slow process the £35 million raised from the disposal of Tara Mines shares is going to be frittered away in a cosmetic operation on petrol prices.

It comes down to this: If the Government were serious about keeping down inflation and if they could have anticipated the increase in petrol prices, they would not have imposed this extra duty by way of resolution on budget day. Since they now know with the benefit of hindsight that that decision and the assurances given by the Minister to this House were wrong, it behoves the Government to surrender, in the national interest, the cost of this matter to the Exchequer.

What I am saying, in effect, is that this is an inflationary provision. It is one which is having a serious effect on the overall consumer price index. It would have had a more serious effect were it not for the steps taken by the Government in relation to abusing the Irish National Petroleum Corporation to disguise the full effect. It is something which damages the country on every front — in relation to tourism, industry, business, the consumer price index and the ordinary person's living standards. It is unjustificable, it flies in the face of everything we are talking about in terms of trying to reduce Ireland's disadvantages in Europe and increases transport costs in a peripheral area of the Community. On those grounds I reiterate the opposition of the Progressive Democrats, which was made clear at the time of the budget, to this measure and we are opposing the section.

Speaker.P: I agree with the Deputy when he says that I am not a clairvoyant in the matter of oil prices. Petrol prices are reviewed every month by the Minister for Industry and Commerce. The 5p. increase in excise duty in January represented a reduction that was available in January; it represents less than 0.1 per cent on the consumer price index. There was no way any of us could have known a ship would run aground in Alaska and knock out the Alaskan pipeline which supplied oil to America. As a result, the Americans came to Europe to buy up all the available petrol supplies. On 1 April every year — you can set your watch by it — the international oil industry stock up petrol for the summer months. Because of the very mild weather there was an over-supply of gas oil and a shortage of petrol. That, coupled with the Americans buying all the available petrol in Europe had the effect of pushing up the price of petrol on the Rotterdam market.

MainHeading.P: We could speculate on what the price may be for the rest of the year but only one week ago it was reported on a morning radio programme that Saudi Arabia expected international crude prices to go to $25 per barrel. The same afternoon crude oil prices had dropped back to $18 per barrel on the Rotterdam market. It is not possible to forecast what the price may be.

Speaker.P: Mandy Rice Davies will look after that.
One would expect someone in the oil business, like Saudi Arabia, to know more about it than I. They claimed that the price would go to $25 but on the same day it dropped to $18.

The Government take the view that the INPC run their business over a full year period, not over a month or two months. The best advice on the future trend in oil prices is that they will come down in the second half of this year. Consequently we lose money in one part of the year but make it in the other part. We have no intention, good, bad or indifferent, of using the money from the sale of Tara Mines shares to prop up an artificial price in INPC. As the Minister for Energy has already stated, that money will be used to develop and modernise refining capacity at Whitegate.

Another development in the oil industry in that they have taken out a lot of their refining capacity, in America and elsewhere, and not replaced it. Those who study the trends will know what is happening in the oil industry, that the major portion of the profit is being taken at the refining end where the companies are in control.

MainHeading.P: If one wants to examine what the position should be vis-à-vis crude oil to petrol one should refer to the time when crude oil was 28.5 dollars per barrel early in 1984. When it was that price the price of petrol was the same as it is now. One must ask why, if crude oil prices fell back from 28.5 dollars to less than 20 dollars per barrel, petrol prices should be so high. It all comes out of the same barrel of crude. That distortion exists and I hope the Fair Trade Commission inquiry will focus on that aspect. Crude oil prices are down nine dollars per barrel but we do not seem to have had a reduction in the price of petrol. Some interesting questions remain to be answered in relation to that. Prices are reviewed on a monthly basis and in January I could not have known that we would run into a serious supply problem that would result in an increase in the price in the next few months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Having listened to the Minister I cannot accept that he was fully advised by the Department of Industry and Commerce before he made his budgetary decision. Clearly, in the budget speech the Minister said that there would be a reduction at the pumps which would compensate for the increase in excise duty.
And there was.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Within 12 days that reduction was lost and the price at the pumps went up again. The Taoiseach, when taking the Financial Resolutions on budget night, gave a commitment that the price at the pumps would reduce. The information available to all of us on that night was that the commitment could not be kept. There is enough on the record to show the serious doubts we had about the promise that the price at the pumps would reduce. The lead-in time before circumstances such as the value of the dollar or the price of crude tips into the retail price of petrol is more than two weeks but within two weeks of the budget statement the price at the pumps had gone up.

MainHeading.P: I am not casting any aspersions on the Minister who did his job on budget night but I would argue strongly that the relevant information was available or should have been available in the Department of Industry and Commerce. The trigger time is certainly not two weeks and anything that would have happened within two weeks of the budgetary announcement should have been, and would have been, known in the Department of Industry and Commerce and, probably, in the Department of Energy. Something went wrong in the line of communication from the Department of Energy to the Department of Industry and Commerce and the Minister for Industry and Commerce and on to the Minister for Finance. There is no point in saying that the Government, and the administration, acted in all innocence on budget night about the expectation that the price at the pumps would drop to compensate for the excise increase and that the price would stay down. That argument does not stand up.

Some of us were, like I was for a short time, in a position to monitor the flow through of the hardening position of the dollar, the increase in crude prices, how the review takes place periodically and how we come to have an announcement of an increase or reduction about the fifth of each month. A mechanism has been in place for a long time. The point I wish to stitch into the record is that the lead-in time is longer than two weeks. The increase occurred within two weeks of the budget and there is no doubt that that information was or should have been, available in the relevant Department. I accept that the Minister acted in a bona fide manner on the night of the budget and that he spoke on the basis of the information available to him at that time. I am not making any accusations against him but there was a breakdown in the system. It should not happen again. When breakdowns like that can occur within the relevant Departments one must come to the conclusion that they are not the greatest people to go tiger-shooting with. I would prefer to have more reliable allies behind my back if I was taking on the oil companies than those who could not see a fortnight ahead from the relevant information that should have been available.

I accept that a lot of what has happened since was unpredictable. On the night of the budget I argued that the price of crude oil was almost 18 dollars per barrel and Deputy O'Malley contradicted me and said it was back down to about 17 dollars per barrel. Texas crude, in the days when we used get CNN in my part of the country, was over 18 dollars a barrel the week before the budget. North Sea Brent might have been slightly lower, about 16.5 or 17 dollars per barrel. There was no expectation at that stage that the price would go above 20 dollars per barrel but it has gone above that price and slipped back again. I take the Minister's point that he is not responsible for the activities of drunk tanker captains off the coast of Alaska and we would not expect him to be responsible for such events.

Speaker.P: He washes his hands of all those occurences. He tries to evade his responsibility.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): It is true to say that the gentleman in charge of that tanker did not cause the whole problem in Ireland. He had some influence on it but it was a fairly marginal one and was temporary. In the spring time the trend was upward and that was accompanied by a dollar which was strengthened and is continuing to do so. There has been a fall in the price of crude but the dollar is strengthening. One may balance one against the other but there is no guarantee that the price is going to drift down in the autumn, as the Minister optimistically suggested on the last occasion he took Questions in the House. The price of crude may reduce to 18 dollars or 19 dollars per barrel, or lower, but if the dollar continues to strengthen the swings and roundabouts will come into effect and we will continue to have problems.

MainHeading.P: I should like to deal with the activities of the Minister for Industry and Commerce and that bogus war he declared on the oil companies. That was a pure cod and it diminished the standing of the Government and of the Minister. For an administration which purports to believe in a market economy and in market forces to be in north County Dublin, King Canute-like, looking out at the waves being engendered by international oil prices and currency fluctuations and saying one could keep them out with a four-pronged fork is nothing short of ridiculous. The Minister for Industry and Commerce got involved in a lot of unseemly stunting and blustering and we are still left with that particular bubble in the oil pipeline. The Minister's bluster is not yet out of the pipeline because the increase that came through last week is not the full increase. When trick-of-the-loop economics is applied in an attempt to turn back the strength of market forces which are inevitable there will be severe problems.

The Irish National Petroleum company will be the victim. This is against everything that the previous Government stood for and is against everything that the leading members of this Administration are on the record as standing for in respect of the running of State companies. A State company is being forced to run at a loss. The Taoiseach, and the Minister for Finance, said on numerous occasions that the standards which apply in the private sector will have to apply in the commercial State bodies. They have said that the same disciplines will have to apply and that those State companies will have to run their affairs so as to make a profit. That is fair and we agree on that. We are not in the business of carrying passengers. However, to put a company like the INPC in the position that it is effectively subsidising the price of petrol is to put them in a most invidious position. I should like the Minister to put figures on this. I have been told that Whitegate is now losing somewhere between £1 million and £1.5 million a month. I do not know if that figure is accurate but somebody should put a figure on this loss. There is no point in saying that they bought it cheap so they can sell it cheap. That is not the way it works. If it was bought cheaply but has to be replaced dearly, they will have to move the price at the appropriate time.

I do not think the Irish National Petroleum Company will last for very long — I do not know what the intentions of the Government are in this regard — carrying that below cost selling and loss trading. While they may last for a short period I think the limit on this will be four or five weeks. I am seriously worried now about the antics of the Minister for Industry and Commerce who got us into this situation by declaring a phoney war which he cannot possibly win and which is having repercussions now on the Irish National Petroleum Company. When that is coupled with the sale of the Government's stake in Tara Mines and the availability of a great chunk of money — £25 million or £26 million — for the refurbishment of Whitegate there is a temptation to use the capital sum which accrued to the State to subsidise the price of fuel. We are all for low cost economies and keeping energy costs down but forcing a State company to trade at a loss is not the way to do business and is very shortsighted.

Already there has been a 5p increase in a gallon of petrol, which occured on budget night. It was only a week before the budget that the price of diesel went up something like 8p a gallon. How anybody could have come into the House and said that the increased excise on petrol would be cancelled out when the week before very similar factors had triggered an increase in the price of auto diesel is difficult to sustain. We had that increase, it went down for two weeks and then it came back up, and now we have the 5 May increase. I think there is another increase on the way because the Minister has not allowed the full increase as a result of the market forces to come through so that there will be a June increase. There is also the increase that was lagged because of the Whitegate situation. We need clarification on this aspect. What we need is a statement on what increases are imminent and not inquiries into the conduct of the petrol company and that kind of smokescreen. These inquiries might have some merit in calmer times but now they look as if they are simply engineered distractions to give some credibility to a Minister who measured it wrong.

There is a very serious side to this because it is putting up costs. If it is for international reasons we do not have a whole lot of choice in it because we have not got the kind of revenue resources anyway where we can use tax foregone to keep prices down at the pump. If the Minister for Finance is correct and things begin to settle at the end of the year so that there will be a reduction anyway, we should see ourselves through the sticky patch by following the market forces and allowing the prices to come down when conditions justify that.

It has a more serious effect than that on the price of energy: it has an effect on confidence. When a senior Minister of Government is seen to be bungling publicly it does not help and when that kind of bungling runs into the inflation figures and there is a widespread belief, as there is now, that a deliberate attempt has been made to keep down the consumer price index figures for 16 May that does not help confidence either. It looks as if the CPI will be just under 4 per cent on 16 May. There has been mention of a figure of 3.9 per cent and last week the Minister talked about 3.75 per cent for the year. However, it is now expected that it will be 3.9 per cent as a result of the petrol increase on 5 May. If I am right there will be another significant increase in June and on 10p of that there is the question of the Irish National Petroleum Company and a strengthening in the dollar. The exchange rate yesterday for the dollar was $1.39 to the Irish pound, the strongest it has been since August last year, I think. Whatever about the trend in the price of crude that strengthening in the dollar will be a counter current which will negative any gain there may be in the drop in the price of crude.

Those are a number of issues of a general nature which the Minister should provide the House with information on. First — and I am not putting this to the Minister in any political way — he should try to project what increases are there now on the basis of the evidence available. How long does the Minister think these increases will be in the system before the price comes back down to where it was on budget night? How does he relate the increasing cost in the price of petrol and diesel to the consumer price index and overall inflation not only in 1989 terms but also for the 12 month period from say, June to June or from mid-May to mid-May so that we will get the full year bang of the energy increases rather than taking half year calculations and making the effect look smaller than what it actually is? I should like to hear the Minister's views on these issues before we conclude this section.

I should also like the Minister to refresh our memories again and tell us, in millions of pounds, what the total take in a full year will be from the 5p excise which was put on petrol and the consequential increases on diesel and so on so that if a decision was taken today not to go ahead with this increase we would know how much the Exchequer would be short.

Speaker.P: I was watching the Chester races in my office while at the same time listening to the very reasoned tones of the Minister. I had to leave my office to come across to the House because his folksy style of debate, reminescent of Ronald Reagan at his best, makes him seem to be a most rational man.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): He is a younger man than that.

However, neither he nor his colleagues were as reasonable about the world price of oil during the four and a half years we were on that side of the House. There were impassioned cries from Fianna Fáil, in Opposition, about the price of petrol. As a Deputy who comes from the Border area one Saturday afternoon I had to watch the then spokesman on Finance, Deputy O'Kennedy, when he came to Newry with a fanfare of trumpets to assess the situation in the Border area. He had more photographers with him on that occasion than Mrs. Gorbachev had on her visit to Ireland.
That is saying something.

He acknowledged the plight of the people who lived in my deprived area but like all Fianna Fáil fairy tales he did nothing about it when he got into power. I want to ask the Minister if it is the intention of the Government to destroy all businesses in the Border region. No Government in the past 20 years — including Fine Gael Governments — have recognised the plight of the people in the Border area and in particular the unfortunate traders, many of whom have gone under. In recent years we have had to deal with the spectre of sheriffs collecting in an area where traders should have been subsidised by the Government of the day.

MainHeading.P: The Minister mentioned carrying out an inquiry, which I believe is a smokescreen. The inquiry should be carried out into the immoral size of the State take from petrol. The differential in the price of petrol is £1.20 between Newry and my town of Dundalk, an incredible differential driving people across the Border in hordes. At one stage some years ago I likened the cavalcade to a pilgrimage to Mecca, there were so many people going across, when the Sunday Independent carried a revealing photograph taken from a helicopter showing the cavalcade of cars three miles long. That sight can still be seen in any part of the Border area and will be with increasing frequency because of the latest decision to increase the price of petrol. Why does the State not take a lesser take in order to help unfortunate motorists in Border areas and more particularly those unfortunate people who continue to endeavour to provide a service at petrol pumps for people living in those areas? For example, there are no petrol stations open in the town of Clones, the petrol being available in County Fermanagh. That is the fault of the Irish Government and nobody else's. I have been told in Dundalk of people driving into petrol stations for 25p worth of petrol to get them to the promised land just three miles down the road. How on earth can people be expected to remain in business in those wartime conditions without any help, subsidisation or indeed any type of rates relief from this Government. We must also remember that a trader will be paying the same rates as five years ago when he may have had a weekly turnover of approximately £4,000 or £5,000 whereas today he might have a weekly turnover of £100. There has been no recognition of the plight of traders in Border areas.

Although petrol is the real attraction it is not the only one. When families get used to travelling across the Border at weekends they tend to buy their Sunday joint, have their shoes repaired and buy other household commodities. This means there is a huge haemorrhage of money across the Border essentially on account of the greed of the Irish Government extracting too much tax out of a lucrative market. The motorist is an easy target and has no protection. Unfortunately, traders who have survived in Border areas have received no protection from this or any previous Government over the past 20 years.

I might remind the Minister that, in Border areas, the law of diminishing returns obtains. I would ask him to recognise that fact, when I will be the first to applaud him. The price of petrol is too dear in this State. This means the Minister is consigning a whole area along the Border, encompassing five countries, if not more, from which people travel in order to fill their tanks with petrol, leading to a huge hole in our economy. I exhort the Minister for Finance to be the first Minister to acknowledge that fact and reduce the price of petrol to a realistic level. The year 1992 is not far off. With this in mind surely some type of levelling off, however small, could be initiated. If the economy of the Border region is to be sustained it must receive some help but it has received none over the past 20 years. People living in Border areas are saying in increasing numbers to all political parties, “a plague on both your houses”. I ask the Minister to acknowledge what he knows to be a fact and help those people.

Speaker.P: In reply to Deputy McGahon I should say we must recognise what is the reality, that is that petrol is dearer here than across the Border. The gap has been narrowed somewhat as a result of the number of increases granted in the United Kingdom but there still remains a long way to go.

MainHeading.P: The proposals for the harmonisation of taxes in 1992 have been around for a long time. They have not received any great degree of support within the member states. Consequently the new Commissioner for fiscality and customs union affairs, Madame Schrivener, is expected to put a new set of proposals in relation to the harmonisation of taxes to the Commission within the next couple of weeks. It is quite clear that she is not proceeding with the older set of proposals which had not received any measure of agreement. One cannot anticipate what will be contained in the new set of proposals. For example, she may adopt a different approach altogether and go for approximation on a regional basis; I do not know; that is pure speculation at this stage. Let us hope that the new proposals will receive a greater degree of support than the last lot so that we can move toward harmonisation of taxes between now and 1992. That is the only realistic way in which the problems in Border areas about which Deputy McGahon spoke can be alleviated.

I would like to be in the position of saying that I did not need money, that money was not required by the Exchequer, that I could narrow the gap. However, the House will know full well the financial problems confronting us, that, while we have reduced the borrowing requirement as a percentage of Gross National Product, we cannot stop there. Certainly I will take appropriate steps as soon as I know what objectives must be achieved in the area of harmonisation of taxes. At the same time I will continue to point out to the Community in Brussels that the Exchequer problems posed for us, on the basis of the former proposals, were such that they could not be resolved by an Irish Government or economy on the one hand harmonising taxes with a huge loss to the Exchequer — emanating from one side in Brussels — while, on the other side, the Commission points out to us that we must get our national finances in order. They constitute two contradictory directions to us from Brussels. At the same time, from a Community point of view, it is unrealistic to think that we could take on board the type of Exchequer loss of revenue we would be forced to incur in order to undertake that task. It is just not realistic. It may well be that the new proposals, having taken account not alone of our problems but those of the British, the Danes and others, will constitute a more realistic approach.

What else could we do in relation to the Border countries? I recognise the problem fully — I do not live that far from the Border myself — which is that whenever there has been a price differential of anything more than 5 per cent or 6 per cent, there is always this cross-Border traffic with its attendant distortion of trade.

The 48-hour rule we introduced was beneficial — I know Deputy McGahon would be the first to admit it — and is still maintained there. It is a question of whenever the case might come up at the European Court but, as far as I am concerned, it will obtain until I am forced to abolish it. Indeed I am not so sure we will lose the case in the European Court either. I have always contended that it is a distortion of trade that is taking place. Equally the Community must ensure that no distortion of trade takes place in contravention of their competition rules. It will be an interesting case to follow whenever it arises. People appear to assume that we will lose the case. I am not so sure at all that we will lose it.

I recognise and know the problems caused by the price differential in petrol to which Deputy McGahon referred. I am aware of the number of petrol stations that have closed down, that sell only a few gallons of petrol to take people across the Border. However, I might point to another problem, that I regard as a very serious development, the smuggling of petrol and diesel. Since coming into the Department of Finance I have been examining ways and means of devising a licensing system for dealing in petrol. The proposal here today constitutes a minor one but is a step in the right direction. Such a licensing arrangement would give Customs and Excise officials authority to seize all records and anything else they needed in that respect. The problem appears to be so serious we may well have to go further. I am examining ways and means of how I can arm Customs and Excise officials in relation to it. For example, I extended their inspection areas 40 miles from the Border. I am at present examining an adjustment of that mileage. It must be acknowledged that there is big money being made out of smuggling activities. I am examining ways and means of trying to prevent it. Apart from the distortion of trade it constitutes a big loss to the Exchequer.

I am quite sure Deputy Noonan was aware at the time he asked that there is not available to me here on this kind of debate the information that is available in the Departments of Industry and Commerce or Energy in regard to endeavouring to project what might be the price of oil over the next 12 months, or how the dollar might fare——

Speaker.P: The Minister had them on budget night.

On the evening of the budget we did not have the next 12 months projections for the price of petrol and oil or for the performance of the dollar. The Deputy must be joking. The dollar could affect prices if it continued to get stronger. I carried out an analysis recently and when I looked at 1987 as compared with 1988 — with the fluctuations in the dollar alone and that aspect of it — strangely enough the fluctuations in 1987 balanced out the fluctuations in 1988. For the first quarter of this year the wide divergence in the value of the dollar only represented parameters of 142 to 146. It goes up and down but over a two and a half year period it balances out. In an analysis of what happened over the last two and a quarter years you can discount the dollar but if you want to take the first quarter in it is a penny a gallon against the oil companies in Rotterdam spot prices. I think Deputy Noonan would also know from his own experience in the Department of Industry and Commerce that half way through the month one just does not know. The formula is based on what movements take place in Rotterdam on a mean class average for whatever month one is talking about. For the month of May the movements would be reflected in a review about the fifth, sixth or seventh of the month. But it does reflect what happens in the whole month.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): By the 25th the Minister for Industry and Commerce would have a very good idea of what would be the position on the 5th of the following month.

The Deputy knows quite well that in the preparation of a budget one does not wait until the morning of the budget to put the figures in. He knows what is involved in the preparations and how far in advance one operates. We are not talking realistically when we talk about the 25th of the month in that respect. We are talking about two weeks before the end of January. The Deputy knows as well as I do that he does not know the position.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Your speech was cleared at the special Cabinet meeting on the Sunday morning.

There was no Cabinet meeting on the Sunday morning. I can tell you that copies of my speech went to the printers on the Friday evening. I was not at a Cabinet meeting on the Sunday morning nor on the Saturday morning and I was not at a Cabinet meeting on Monday morning either. I had my business done, put away, organised on time. There were no last minute Cabinet meetings; the figures were all fed in well in advance of 25 January.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Was it done before Christmas?
It was not done before Christmas. What I have to reject is that what happens in the second half of the month can have a considerable effect——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): But it did not.

——one way or the other, up or down and nobody could forecast with any certainty what the value of the dollar will be in two weeks from now or what the price might be. Whatever one may say about the public inquiry I want to see a certain number of things coming from it. As I said earlier, and I was only drawing from memory — though I have a paper on oil prices which is very interesting — I have the full run down on petrol for every month from July 1984 to April 1989 — in July 1984 petrol on the spot in Rotterdam which is the basis of the formula we use, was $265.77 at a time when the barrel of crude oil was $28.24. Now we come to the month that sparked off the first confrontation with the Minister and the oil companies, the month of March. Regarding the review of 5 April concerning the 5p, the Minister and the Government took the view that because gifts were costing in or about that amount, in the interests of customers it was better to do away with the gifts and give them petrol at the price it should be sold at. I am sure there is no Deputy in this House who would disagree with me — Deputy Noonan has had his own experience — when I say that there is no petrol sales competition in this country. There are a few small Irish companies who try to create some competition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: What about the small fellow who was offering gifts?
What about him?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: He lost 3p on the gallon.
Why would he lose 3p off it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: Because he cut back.

Who will cut him back? I will tell the Deputy how it works. When I took the 10p from them I told them they could discontinue the gifts if they so wished and make a contribution to the 10p. At that stage no retailer was carrying any cost of the gifts. The response of the major oil companies in that situation was: “We will put half the cost of the gifts on to the retailer.” They forced the retailer to pay half the cost of the gifts. We are not affected by the retailers margin. It was the oil companies and the suppliers who forced the retailers to pay the cost of the gifts. That is exactly what happened.
What do you propose to do now about the absence of competition between the retailers?

There is no competition and I hope that the result of this inquiry will show quite clearly that there is no competition and that the distribution system in this country will be tackled once and for all.
If the Minister knows there is no competition why make an inquiry about it?
The Deputy can direct that to my colleague, the Minister for Industry and Commerce when he next answers Questions. He is forming that as the basis of it.
You were there before that yourself, Minister.

These are very interesting factors to look at. Now we will come back to the month which was in dispute — the month of March, for the April review. During that month the on the spot Rotterdam price for a barrel of crude was $17.48 and the price of petrol was $206, in April the price of crude went up to $19.83 and the petrol soared to £268. If you go back to look for $268 you will find that in July 1984 when crude was $28.24 the price of petrol was $265. Those are the questions that need to be addressed in an inquiry and I hope they are addressed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): The cost of refining the crude had gone up four years later. What is the point in throwing up figures at two different dates when you are only taking——
What I am trying to say is this——
The Minister is saying what suits himself.
I am stating international facts on the oil industry which the Deputy can either accept or reject. The cost of refining is minute, as the Deputy knows.
What does the Minister intend doing about it?

I will allow the Deputy to discount the increased cost of refining but I hold my view very strongly that we are not getting petrol at a price that can be related to the barrel of crude and it is the same barrel from which the petrol is taken. It does not matter whether it was a barrel of crude three years ago or a barrel of crude today. The only difference is the additional costs in refining that have taken place.
What does the Minister intend doing about it?
I am telling the Deputy that it does not represent $10 a barrel in the book and I hope the inquiry clears that up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Why did the Minister not do something about it when he was Minister for Industry and Commerce?

Now that the Deputy has asked the question I will take him back to July 1987 when I took 10p straight off the retailers. I did that because their margins were too high. I will give the position as obtained in July 1987. In July 1987 the barrel of crude oil cost $18.8 and the price of petrol was $194.57 which, when I calculated the margins, I considered to be too fat and I took 10p off. Now look at the position and compare it to the big row which erupted in April concerning the 5p when the price of the barrel of crude had dropped to $17.48 but yet the petrol was costing £206.83. The retailers were getting more for petrol in April when the row erupted than when I took 10p off them in July 1987. I will give the bottom line cost of the 5p.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: How much did the Government get?
Deputy Burke must be a softie to let them increase their margin.
I will answer that one in a minute. The income from the 5p for 1989 will be £9.5 million and for a full year, £10.5 million. That is what we are talking about.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): It is a nice bit of money.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: I have noticed a marked difference in the Minister since he went to the other side of the House. When he was on this side of the House there were no problems. At that time he was concerned about self-financing, tax cuts, about driving the economy and getting everything moving. These were the Thatcherite policies. In relation to the closure of hospitals he said they were dreadful. I recall the theatrical performance here every Wednesday night. Who was always shoved in for the last 15 minutes? It was the bold Albert. He always came in without notes —“give her the holly, Albert”, was one of the expressions we heard while the boys at the back were shouting: “Thatcherite”, “heartless Government”, etc. My God, what a change in two years. I often sit here and say to myself if only the Holy Ghost had descended on them two and a half or three years ago this country would be booming because when the then Government was trying to do something he was telling the electorate not to mind them, that there was no need for whatever was being done, that it was all lies. I want to ask a few questions about what happened.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): If Charlie had gone to Lough Derg sooner we would have had no problems.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: The sense of responsibility, which is great stuff, has come over Fianna Fáil. I break down and cry sometimes when listening to interviews on radio and television. About this nice man, Mr. Haughey.
And the archdeacon, Gay Byrne, is another fellow who has been converted.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: I read in my newspapers where Ministers X and Y have been out addressing this and that conference and telling the private sector to prepare themselves for 1992. Do the Government ever realise that 1992 is coming? What will happen on 1 January 1993 when all the barriers have gone? The Government are not preparing themselves for 1992, but widening the gap all the time. In this instance there is the difference in the price of a gallon of petrol between here and Britain. Suddenly, it will be 1 January 1993. I do not know whether “Uncle Albert” and “Auntie Charlie” will be over in Brussels with their hands out, waiting for people to give them money to balance the books.
The Deputy's party were.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: All I know from what I have been told and have read and from all the documentation produced, is that those barriers are going. We will all be able to drive our vehicles north or south, to buy our cars, drive across the border and get our petrol and nobody will be able to stop us.
Pigs will be flying.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: The Minister need not worry about inquiring into smuggling, because smuggling will disappear. That artificial boundary or border will be gone.
We would make a few quid between now and 1993 if I could stop the smuggling.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: What I suggest the Minister should be doing is using his energies to prepare us as a nation for 1992. It is very easy to continue putting an extra 5p on a gallon of petrol, and now there is another 12p. My authority from the Border counties tell me that the 12p that has been put on our petrol must be compared with 8p across the Border. There is another gap of 4p. This, plus the Minister's 5p, is 9p and 1992 is not too far away.

I look forward to it because I shall get cheaper goods, but with regard to the country's finances we are not doing anything to prepare ourselves. The Minister is lecturing other people to get their act together and prepare for 1992 but this will sound very hollow if his Government — and he as Minister for Finance has to direct that Government into preparing themselves for 1992 — do not do that job. You cannot keep telling everybody else to do it when you are not doing it yourselves. It is the soft option that is taken up all the time — to put on another 5p when there is a gap in the figures at the end of the many Cabinet meetings the Government have at budget time.
Is that the way the Deputy's Government used to do it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: The Minister and the Taoiseach have a little chat and decide that the market can take another 5p, and up the price goes.
An historic deal there.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: Let the Minister not try to tell me that he and his colleagues do not operate on that basis because there is sufficient evidence to show they have done so since the foundation of the State, and they have not changed that much.
We did not do it this time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: I agree that they have been converted somewhat, but they are not that pure. What really concerns me is the lack of preparation for 1992.
I will not join the Deputy at the races on Saturday if he does not stop.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: Let the Minister not worry about my going to the races. I can afford to go to the races on a Saturday afternoon after my clinics. I am entitled to two hours' relaxation. I see the Minister there often, looking very spritely.
I was there the Saturday before the budget.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: I shall be talking about the racing industry in Ireland soon.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): That was to inspire confidence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: I am genuinely concerned, having listened to the person whom I regard as the expert in Europe over the last number of years — and everybody in this House will have to admit it——
Mr. Sutherland.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: ——one man, peter Sutherland. The best advice I could give to the Minister would be to invite him in one afternoon for a talk.
I have talked to Peter often.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: I do not think the Minister got this message at all. I think he needs a bit of schooling, as they say in racing parlance. He has not really copped on to the job he will have over the next couple of years, with this extra 5p a gallon on petrol and blinding us with the sheet of paper about the spot price and all that. The only fellow who worries about the price of a gallon of petrol is the fellow at the petrol pump who hands out the money. You can talk about the spot price and anything else but we are talking about a Government that are increasing their take when they should be reducing it in preparation for 1992.

There is another side to this, and I shall give the Minister one bit of recognition. He has plenty of experience running a business. He knows as well as I do that one of the things that are crippling our industry is the continuous high cost of telecommunications, postage, transport costs, insurance and the price of petrol. We ask why the private sector are not expanding, but look at the costs. The Government are contributing to these costs with another 5p in this instance and the 12p they approved a couple of days ago. That is 17p this Government have added to the price of a gallon of petrol in the last three months. They can agrue what way they like, he as Minister for Finance has stood over a 17p increase in the price of a gallon of petrol in the last three months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): And another 20p coming.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: My colleague has taken the words out of my mouth. By the time we are halfway through this year we will be talking about 30p or 40p. That widens the gap even further.
The Deputy would get a job as the Wednesday night performer. Let him keep on.
The old time music hall.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: There is no doubt in my mind about it. The Minister is not giving a good example to people to prepare for 1992. He is doing absolutely nothing to reduce costs in order to create employment. Let him not give us these lectures——
I do not intend to lecture.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: ——about the need for rectitude and responsibility. I hope, the Minister will not threaten us with an election because of what I have said.
I would not do a thing like that.
It will not be his decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: We are concerned about that. His credibility is being damaged every day he behaves in this manner. He personally has stood over an increase of 17p on a gallon of petrol. It is about time he had second thoughts about this and considered reducing the price by 17p to give us some chance to prepare for 1992.

The Minister spoke a lot of codswallop about world prices. The problem with the price of petrol is the size of the Government take. I indict my colleagues on my own front bench who did not get the message either when I was pleading on behalf of the Border region. Now this Government are stonewalling in time honoured fashion. It is the size of the take, based on greed, that is the problem with the price of petrol. I would describe Governments in the recent past as being burglars who burgled the unfortunate Irish people, the Irish motorist and those in other areas who are easy prey.
Gamblers.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Drinkers.

Drinkers and smokers, yes, and reformed terrorist organisations, too, who knew the way to the Irish banks in their time. I want to acknowledge the effectiveness of the 48 hour rule and the initiative taken within a couple of days of the Government coming into office. That kept immense amounts of money in our economy, but it did sweet Fanny Adams for the Border region. People on trips from Kenmare and Kinsale were not coming to spend their money in the Border region, they were going across the Border and leaving unbelieveable sums of money with Margaret Thatcher. That has stopped to a large extent and the Irish nation benefits, but the Minister is now giving a charter to increase smuggling and he himself made reference to smuggling. Because his Department cannot quantify the figures he turns a blind eye; it is not happening. As petrol is being smuggled into every county in Ireland, it is not just the Border retailers who are hit, it is people all over the country. It is a very lucrative trade. Many gangs, some possibly IRA influenced, are involved because the money is so big. It is said that up to £5,000 profit can be made in a full tanker. That is big money by any standards. The Minister is encouraging that because he cannot quantify it. The Department are like dummies, snap happy and turn a blind eye, it is not happening. I tell the Minister it is happening and it is seriously damaging the economy.

There is another side to the equation. Deputy Barrett referred very eloquently to 1992 and suggested that the Minister and his Government had been remiss in the period leading up to 1992. They are going to continue complacently, like a rat nibbling poison he knows will kill him. They are going to screw the Irish motorist until the advent of 1992, instead of gently reducing the price of petrol in reasonable phases.

I believe 1992 will not happen. It is a giant con as far as the Government are concerned and the Minister has hinted over the last two years that the man in the street need not look forward with heightened anticipation to 1992. I have no doubt the Government of the day will find ways and means to get lucrative returns from differentials. It might come under a name, perhaps licences, but it will be there. It is part of the general political charade.

MainHeading.P: I want to refer to the plight of the 2,000 customs officials. What is to happen to them? Are they to be put out on grass, maybe consigned to hell or to Connaught? There is grave concern among those people. They are not being given much information from the Government. One hundred and twenty have made their lives in my home town and naturally, they are concerned. Most of them have families. Those men perform a very good job for the nation. They are confronted with the problem of dealing with smuggling and in recent years their lives have been at great risk. There have been plenty of documented cases of them being assaulted and guns having been trained on them because smuggling is so lucrative and the gangs have become very sophisticated.

Customs officers' homes are watched. The smugglers are in command of walkie-talkies and if a client is sitting outside the custom house they know when he is leaving and inform their colleagues along the line. There are not enough customs officers to deal with the flood of smuggling not alone of petrol but of different consumer goods coming across the Border and the very lucrative trade in drink which the Minister is aware of. He is trying to hold back a torrent of smuggling with a handful of customs officers along the Border.

In Dundalk in recent years lorries and goods have been seized and placed in custom compounds and on the same night gangsters have broken into the compounds and taken those goods and lorries back. No Irish Government have come to terms with the depth of smuggling in the Border area and the forces trying to keep them at bay. It will be scant recognition of the efforts of those officers over the years if they are put out to grass. I am sure the Minister recognises their difficulty, but can he give any indication how they will be dealt with? Will they be absorbed into the system or is there a future for them in the Revenue Commissioners?

Speaker.P: I want to respond to Deputy McGahon and Deputy Barrett in relation to the Border and 1992. I assure Deputy McGahon and the whole House that there will be no instant harmonisation in this country. I have said many times, and am on the record as saying, it will be a gradual process. We will have three Fianna Fáil budgets to go between now and 1992 in which I can take on board the harmonisation process when I know what the process is going to be. I have explained in this debate that the old set of proposals are now off the table. Deputy McGahon, a good, solid, sensible man, and Deputy Barrett would not buy a pig in a poke, neither would I. When I know what the harmonisation proposals are and when I see them getting a measure of support within the Community to be implemented, then I will take the necessary gradual steps, whatever they are.

With regard to why I put on this or that, taxation is not an a la carte menu. If you say not to take £10 million out of one area, that means £10 million less will be given in personal tax reductions or some such thing. You make a judgement at budget time as does any other Minister for Finance, and try to get the best balanced budget you can and respond to the needs as you see them. That is exactly what I did. The situation was not clear when I put those figures together. I made the best effort I could. I do not think for one minute the Deputies opposite are going to accept every single thing I do, and why should they? They have their views and I have mine. I am in that seat to take the decisions. I took them and they are on the line, but in no way can you have an a la carte menu in relation to them.

Regarding 1992, it is a pity Deputy Barrett was not with me today at the CII annual dinner to hear the President of the CII enumerate the many improvements that have been brought about over the last couple of years with political consensus in this House and what the country has gained from it.
I am delighted to hear the Minister say the word “consensus”. It is the first time he has used the word. I am delighted.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: It has finally got through to him that he is claiming all the credit.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Is the Minister quoting?
I am quoting the CII President. Deputy Carey attributed the word to me and I was quite happy with that.
I would nearly pass out if the Minister used it.
Do not do that.
Let us hear the Minister without interruption.

The Government had made their effort to prepare the Irish economy for 1992. We have got inflation down. The parties opposite made their contribution to that in their time, and we brought it down the rest of the way. Interest rates are down. As a nation we want to become competitive vis-à-vis inflation, the cost of money, etc. The unit cost increase for Irish manufacturers this year vis-à-vis the UK market will improve by 5 percentage points. That gives them a competitive edge and that is how we will have to continue. It is not fair to suggest that the Government are not preparing the economy for 1992.

In relation to cost competitiveness, there is a great deal of work to be done by the business community and manufacturing industry. All we can do as a Government is prepare the economy, get it as competitive as possible and use the Structural Funds to try to offset some of the cost disadvantages. I recognise that the differential between an Irish exporter getting his product to the marketplace is about 5 to 6 per cent per invoice more than that of somebody in the marketplace itself. That is a cost disadvantage. We can all be good decision-makers in hindsight. If we knew last January what would happen in May we would be great decision makers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: That is the Minister's job.

To gaze into a crystal ball and make a judgment? I made a judgment and I stand over it, right or wrong. Deputies want an à la carte menu but it is not available now, and will not be available, no matter what Government are in power.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: It took a few years to convert the Minister.

I recognise the uncertainty of what the future may hold for customs officers. I should like to be able to tell them their exact position. I assure Deputy McGahon that as soon as the situation crystallises I will let them know where they can be accommodated in the system. There are other aspects of 1992 to be taken into consideration, including the movement of drugs and many other factors. Provisions will have to be put in place to deal with these matters. I will not leave them and their families in uncertainty for one day longer than necessary.

We are doing our bit in relation to 1992 and will continue to do so. It is in the interests of all parties to recognise the serious challenge and the threat of 1992 and none of us should do anything to leave the country in a worse position. The challenges are there to be met and it is up to us to accept them or not.

I spoke on Second Stage about petrol prices and asked the Minister to take into account the hardship being suffered by the people in the western areas in particular. There the people have to travel long distances over roads with myriads of potholes. I am quite sure the Ceann Comhairle when visiting scenic areas of south Tipperary meets some of these blemishes in the roads and is quite aware of this problem. The Minister is from a county where roads are not as good as they used to be.
They will shortly be again.

He understands the difficulty. However, the Minister is ignoring the problem that will arise in 1992, that is, doing away with the Border. In replying to Deputy McGahon about problems in the Border area, the Minister should have indicated that the Department of Finance were thinking of some way to make the price of petrol in Dundalk equal to the price in Newry as a first step towards 1992. We are competing to sell goods in the UK market. The Minister spoke about the comparison of prices and said the difference was only 5 per cent. It may be 5 per cent in some areas but it can be 25 per cent or 30 per cent in others. Transport charges have a vital bearing on the success or failure of industry.

Regarding the creation of employment, the “steady as she goes” policy has been the undoing of the preparation for 1992 which was set in train. The Minister is hanging on to the idea that the rising tide will lift all boats. They must be helped along the way. The harmonisation of petrol prices between ourselves and the UK would be a step forward. I made representations to the previous Government and I have difficulty in understanding what the Department of Finance officers are thinking about when they increase the price of petrol in successive budgets. The increase of five pence in the January budget was supposed to be insignificant, but it was the start of a big increase in costs at a time when we should be moving in the opposite direction. The Minister has ignored the fact that on the international market we are accepting the claim by the petrol companies that they are not charging the Irish economy above the odds for petrol.

MainHeading.P: There is a substantial difference between some of the figures produced by the Commission and those produced by the petrol companies. Claims have been made that a cartel is working and that the petrol companies have being successfully exploiting this economy for many years. The Minister for Finance and the Minister for Industry and Commerce never refer to the fact that the petrol companies are taking an advantage, but I come from a constituency where we are well aware of the cartel and the way they were using aircraft fuel and exploiting high prices for air carriers at Shannon. It was not until the then Minister, Deputy Cooney, gave permission to Aer Rianta to barter with the Russians for the supply of aircraft fuel that the price of such fuel dropped at Shannon and they were able to compete with other international airports for charter flights. The retailer is the sufferer in the current dispute but the companies also have to answer. It is very difficult to know what is happening in the Department of Industry and Commerce because the Minister has somebody else looking after the problem and he is not investigating it himself. It is difficult to see why Deputy Burke has to hide so much and has not come up with a definite decision. Transport is such a vital factor in the economy that these problems should be examined more thoroughly.

The Minister gave the vital information to the House that this five pence increase will yield £10.5 million in a full year. The challenge for politicians is to find some other means to get this £10.5 million. The Minister has been well set up by his advisers in the Department of Finance as to the easiest route to take. I am sorry he took that route.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Debate on this section could have ended well over an hour ago. Most of the points have been made on a number of occasions but I feel compelled, having listened to such a long debate, to make a contribution.

I am delighted to see the doubling of the differential in regard to unleaded petrol. The Minister is tackling that problem in a serious manner. We will expect a huge increase in the sales of unleaded petrol following this.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Carey has just made a point about the way the country is being held up to ransom by the oil companies. This is accepted. The Minister and his colleague, Deputy Burke, have more or less admitted that this is so. They wanted to give the impression of standing up to these “seven sisters”. As everybody knows, however, what they are doing is subsidising the price of oil. I cannot understand why, because there is such a consensus about subsidies that the subsidy on food was abolished. Now the Government are saying oil is more important than food and should be subsidised. It is difficult to understand the philosophy of the Government.

I agree with subsidies on food, particularly in view of the very high price of food. Yet food is the item that is given least importance in the economy by Irish Governments. With this major consensus against subsidisation, this Government appear to be forcing the petrol companies to keep the price of petrol down and are forcing Whitegate to subsidise the oil companies. The oil companies are still making their money as if the Minister had put up the price of petrol. What is it all about? Is it the policy to let prices go up and then people will not buy it because the cannot afford it? That seems to be the system of Government. Why not continue it in this case? What is the difference?

I feel it is very important to keep the price of petrol down. All the discussion has been centred on the motorists, but if all the motorists were brought to a standstill, the price of petrol would still have a major effect on the economy because of distribution, transport, commercial vehicles and various other costs on manufactured goods, food and everything else. We are not keeping the price of petrol down, and I would like to know how the Minister is managing to pay this subsidy.
A few weeks ago we sold a major part of our assets in Tara Mines for £35 million. It was stated very clearly that this £35 million was to go towards the expansion of the refinery in Whitegate.

Speaker.P: Now it is going as a subsidy to the oil companies.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: This is what I would like to ask the Minister. Has that deal gone through yet? Is the Tara Mines share sold and has the £35 million been received by the Minister? If so, is he pushing hard to see that this enhancement of the refinery takes place at the earliest possible moment in order to give us increased capacity, etc., in Whitegate as was outlined by the Minister when the Tara Mines share was being sold? If the Minister got the £35 million, how much of it has already been spent in this subsidy? Was Whitegate given the money and told to use it to subsidise the oil companies?

It is important that we know the financial procedure adopted in Whitegate and with the oil companies. It is important to know where and how the transfers of money take place. Everybody is in the dark on how the deal was done and where the money is coming from. In the final analysis, people want to know why was it necessary to subsidise petrol and why no Minister was the slightest bit worried about the price of newspapers going up by 5p, an 8 per cent increase.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Except one.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: There was an increase in the price of all newspapers except The Irish Press, de Valera's old rag, which stands fair and true and says they will not put up their prices. They got no credit for that. Nobody commented on the effect on inflation of this increase in the price of newspapers, least of all the newspapers who put up their prices.
The oil companies are ripping off the economy and making huge profits which are not reflected in their books. Look at the profits made by the newspapers, by the Independent Newspapers Group.
The Deputy is straying very far from the subject matter of this section.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: I am trying to relate price increases, all the Ministers were so upset about the increase in petrol and why it was important for them to give the impression that they were not allowing a price increase. I merely referred to the increase in the price of newspapers as another recent very substantial increase in the prices of all our newspapers, except The Irish Press group.

MainHeading.P: The reason I rose was to ask about Whitegate. I have always been an advocate of increasing our own refining capacity. We had an opportunity some years ago to build an oil refinery in the port of Dublin in total opposition to the oil companies who orchestrated a major campaign against that effort. That could have been done without any Government subsidies if they had got the required permissions and assistance, and we would now have opposition to the massive control by the existing multinational oil companies of our oil capacity.

Deputy Carey expressed his gratitude to the Soviet Union for rescuing us from the grip the American multinationals had on our economy. I am very glad Deputy Carey recognises the great assistance the Soviet Union has been to us, particularly to Clare and the mid-west region. The Government have also recognised the importance of that in the battle against the oil companies, and I fully support them in this battle; but the way they have gone about it is the worst of all. They are giving the impression of a major fight against oil companies but they are giving the oil companies everything they were looking for and put it all on to the taxpayer. Both the motorist and the taxpayer are paying for this, not the oil companies.

I would ask the Minister when replying to concentrate on the question of the sale of Tara Mines and upgrading the oil refinery. I want to know what stage it is at, if it will begin this year or if the money is being eroded through this subsidy to the oil companies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): I would like to thank the Minister for providing some of the information I requested in my previous contribution. Certainly a figure of £10.5 million is a significant sum of money in the computation of a budget, and if it is not to be got from increased excise on the price of petrol it will have to be found somewhere else. We simply cannot let a hole of that magnitude develop in the finances. The Minister did not attempt to answer the question I posed about the present level of subsidy from INPC to the oil companies. Are we talking in terms of £1.5 million a month and how long can this go on? That information could be, should be and has to be available to the Minister even though the Department of Industry and Commerce are the primary Department with responsibility in this area.

I would like to reiterate what I said on budget night, 25 January — the Department of Industry and Commerce would have the information available to suggest that the price of petrol was not going down at the pumps on the announcement on 5 February. Whether the Minister's speech was written by the middle of January, before Christmas, on 24 January or on the morning of 25 January does not matter. There were people who should have had the information, because it was not passed on to the Minister he was left in a position where both he and the Taoiseach misled the House on the night of the budget.

The Minister said there is no competition in the price of petrol now. That is a matter the review body will have to examine. I want to make a couple of observations on this. When the Minister says there is no competition I think he means there is no price competition. There is no price competition because people do not know the price of petrol. Most motorists were educated in pounds, shillings and pence and they know the price of petrol in terms of pounds and pence per gallon, but they have no idea of the price when they see the price of petrol displayed on an automatic pump at so many pence per litre. To the average motorist 59.4p or 59.5p a litre means nothing.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): The price differs at different pumps. I am not trying to nominate the figure; I am simply saying that pence and decimal points of pence on an automatic pump mean nothing to the average motorist. They do not know whether they are paying a high or a low price, and there is no price competition at that level.

I had an agreement with the retail outlets, when I was Minister for Industry and Commerce, that they would display the prices and they agreed to do so by poster where the motorist could see them before he committed himself to purchasing the petrol. That was done for a short period of time, but I understand from an item in one of the newspapers last week that this has been discontinued now, and that more than 90 per cent of the retail outlets are no longer displaying the price in terms of pounds and pence per gallon, which is what was agreed at the time. The agreement was that if they continued to display the price in this fashion, the Minister for Industry and Commerce of the day would not fix the price of petrol. If they do not display the price, it should be fixed, whether it be in pence per litre or whatever, and if it is fixed the retail outlets then have a problem.

There were areas of competition other than price competition, such as with the level of service offered but of course no service is being offered now at petrol stations. It is like the story of the old gentleman who found three of his workmen asleep by the avenue, and he said he would give a pound to the man who illustrated that he was the laziest. The third man won on the basis that he told his employer to put the money into his pocket. The same applies when you buy petrol. You pump it yourself, you go to the window or counter and hand over your money or your credit card. If it is after 7 p.m. there is a kind of robotic gesture inside the window where you slide in the money and you then receive your coupon or change. There is no service any more at petrol stations, and there is very little employment as a consequence of the reduction in service. In the first instance there is no price competition because people do not know the price of petrol and, secondly, there is no competition at the level of service.

MainHeading.P: The third area where there was competition was in the dispensing of gifts. People changed from one retailer to another on the basis of the attractiveness of the gifts being offered and there was an element of competition in that. One of the results of withdrawing the gifts is that the only element of overt competition that existed is now gone. I am not advocating gifts, but if there is to be a choice between getting 5p off the price of a gallon of petrol and receiving free red wine glasses everytime you buy £20 worth of petrol, I would opt for the price reduction because that is better for the economy, but the withdrawal of gifts has taken away the only element of competition which was available to the customer at the pumps.

On the face of it there appears to be no competition at all, but that is not so. There is competition which I think will make it very difficult for the Minister to reduce the price of petrol when the review is published. As I understand it, the companies are competing for market share on the basis of controlling outlets, some of which are company outlets. With the private outlets, they are making offers and saying they will give so much of a grant to renovate the premises, provide new pumps, a new canopy and automatic pumps etc. They also offer to build a shop and say they will charge low interest or provide them interest free on condition that the person takes 4,000 gallons of petrol a week from that particular company. There is competition but it is competition that is damaging the Irish economy because it is competition to control the outlets on the market at prices which are fixed by the cartel. Since the companies fix the prices there is no competition at price level — I believe they have been taking more than they should — but they are still competing for market share and they are pushing out the smaller traders all the time.

One of the consequences of this type of competition is that the companies have been so generous in providing loans to the private retailers and have invested so much in colossal canopies, forecourts and automatic pumps that the capital investment has already been made and this in turn will force the price of petrol to stay high to service that capital investment. When the Minister says the price of crude oil was $26 dollars and the price of a gallon of petrol was so much and the difference cannot be explained by increasing refinery costs, he may find his answer in the capital investment which we see at every mile or half mile of the road, through money provided by the companies to establish these ludicrously expensive petrol retail outlets which are a feature of the Irish landscape. This has been accompanied by a total abolition of service because the young people who were employed around the forecourts to clean the windscreens and pump the petrol have been let go. The investment now is in these massive automatic pumps and huge canopies, backed up by the shops etc.

When the Minister examines the position he will find he is trying to lock the stable when the horse has gone because the massive investment has been made by the companies and they need the margin to service the capital cost of that investment. It is a very insidious kind of competition where companies are seeking to control the Irish market by controlling outlets and at the same time fixing prices. It is a pity it has come to that.

I use the roads a lot. I often travel to Dublin and back on the one day, and I pass many petrol stations. There is no doubt that in the last three years or so there has been a colossal investment in pumps, canopies, forecourts and so on but these retail outlets cannot be selling very much. They are springing up like mushrooms all over the place. There are too many of them in the country, they are too well appointed, they are over-capitalised, they provide no service and their prices are high.

I hope the Minister is successful in attempting to control the price of petrol and to cut the margins which I believe the companies are getting. The fly in the ointment will be that the investment has already been made and the companies will be able to produce figures to show that in servicing the investment they will need the margins that now exist, even though those margins are substantially higher than those that pertained on the Minister's statistical table four, five or six years ago.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: In relation to this provision, I recently had the benefit of hearing the Minister for Finance while sharing an interview with him on RTE, insist not once, but five times, that there was no budget provision to increase petrol tax. The Minister said this not just in the quietness of a room but to the assembled million viewers of “Today Tonight” at that time. That chicken has come home to roost. It is sad to see the Minister attempt to hoodwink the public in that way. This Minister cried crocodile tears about the inflation problems created by rising petrol prices but we see that he has put 65 pence on, and not content with that, the agreement that his colleague the Minister for Industry and Commerce announced last week of 11.5 pence increase includes an extra tax take of 2½ pence. This Minister who was so concerned about petrol and inflation is taking not just the 5 pence that we see here today but another 2½ pence out of the latest agreement. It is quite wrong for this Government to approach petrol pricing in this way.

The Minister for Industry and Commerce has decided that the INPC, a company we all believe should operate commercially, should be the swing factor. That Minister, after all his huffing, puffing and fulminating against the oil companies, in which he was joined by the Minister for Finance, said that refining margins, were excessive, that crude prices and petrol prices were going out of line and that the company should not charge so high a price for the refined product, yet he reverted to the formula that was in place before the March rise. They are back to square one. Instead of having the courage to say that the tax take should absorb the shock that might be caused in inflationary terms, they have instead sought that the INPC take that shock.

MainHeading.P: The INPC is a State run company. This Government have made a virtue of their attitude to State run companies. They believe State run companies should be run at arms length free from arbitrary political intervention and should approach problems in a business like fashion. For the Government to step in and force the company to take sustained losses of £3 million a month is not the way to deal with this problem. At the end of the year the INPC will have had a bad year. That company are at the moment seeking joint venture partners who would put in their money to join in a commercial venture. It bodes ill for the success of getting a joint venture partner if arbitrary political intervention to shroud the Minister for Industry's inactivity is used to put that company into difficult trading positions.

The reality about the petrol issue is that the Minister for Industry and Commerce has not done his homework. The Minister for Finance, to give him his due, announced an inquiry into the question of excessive distribution margins last October. His colleague failed to deliver on that and he had to announce again what Deputy Reynolds announced last October. It has been a sad chronicle of mishandling that started with the budget. In the run up to the budget when this 5 pence was imposed the Minister for Industry instructed the oil companies not to pass on to the motorist a price reduction that was due from 5 January. Where was the concern about inflation and about the hardpressed motorist then? It was simply a cynical move to try to shield from the public the ultimate objective of hiking up the tax on 26 January. We can only now hope that the Fair Trade Commission will do the job they should have done six, eight or 12 months ago.

Speaker.P: This ground has been ploughed and furrowed here for the last hour-and-a-half. I repeat for the benefit of Deputy Bruton what I repeated here and on television; I did not put up the price of petrol in the budget nor did the price of petrol go up the day after the budget. It went up subsequently, some two weeks afterwards. As I said here, and Deputy McDowell agreed with me, I am not a clairvoyant. I could not foresee that a ship would go down in Alaska, that it would cut off all the supplies from America and that it would put pressure from America into Europe to supply their scarcity in petrol.
