In retrospect people can say I should have known. These facts were not known. I did not know them. I am repeating this for the third time and I do not want to hold up the House.

In relation to the dispute — and this is unfortunately ploughing the same ground again — the first dispute between the oil companies and the Minister for Industry and Commerce related to 5 pence that the oil companies were claiming would go on following the month of April review. The Government took the view that the 5 pence being spent on gifts would have been better spent by passing it on to the motorist. That disposes of the April issue of 5 pence. During any of the interviews halfway through April I recognised that the price of petrol had gone up some $60 on the Rotterdam price and I said that if it continued even at that level for the rest of the month there would be a price increase to reflect it. That is what has happened.

The Government position in relation to the INPC is that we cannot look at the operations of INPC on the basis on one or two months. The best oil analysts are forecasting a downturn for the second half of the year and already we have seen reductions in the price of crude, down to $18 dollars. One looks at the operations of INPC over the year. One does not judge any business on how it runs for a month or two.

In relation to the money forthcoming from Tara shares, it will not be used to subsidise the consumer in the oil market. That deal is almost legally complete although I am not certain that the money has passed. I will find out about that from the Minister for Energy. In relation to the question raised by Deputy Noonan as to the quantity of petrol they are selling out of Whitegate, and the differential, I do not have that information available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Deputy Bruton says £3 million a month. Is that correct?

I read figures too, but I do not know. I will find out from the Minister for Energy and I will pass the information on. I do not have it available in my brief on the Finance Bill. I have more or less responded to all the questions raised.
Question put.
The Dáil divided: Tá, 67; Níl, 22.

MainHeading.P: Tellers: Tá, Deputies V. Brady and D. Ahern; Níl, Deputies Kennedy and Colley.
Question declared carried.
NEW SECTION.

Speaker.P: I move amendment No. 42a:
In page 44, before section 37, to insert the following new section:

MainHeading.P: “37.—The duty on bets imposed by section 24 of the Finance Act, 1926, shall (subject and without prejudice to the provisions of section 20 of the Finance Act, 1931) be charged, levied and paid on bets entered into on or after the first day of January 1990, at the rate of 7.5 per cent of the amount of the bet in lieu of the rate of 10 per cent mentioned in section 31 of the Finance Act, 1985.”.

The amendment before us requests a reduction in off-course betting duty from 10 per cent, the present rate to 7.5 per cent. As such it is not self-explanatory because what we on this side of the House have in mind is that the reduction in off-course betting tax would be accompanied by the imposition of a 1 per cent levy on bookmakers with that 1 per cent or its equivalent to go directly to the Irish Racing Board to improve stakes and facilities at race courses. As an Opposition spokesperson, I am not in a position either to propose the imposition of a charge or the appropriation of money. Therefore, I cannot put down a second amendment to direct how I would like the 1 per cent to be allocated. I am asking the Minister for Finance in this amendment to accept a reduction from 10 per cent to 7.5 per cent in off-course betting tax as from 1 January 1990. I put in that date advisedly. The present rate would continue until January next. In the autumn a separate subhead could be raised in the Vote for the Department of Agriculture and Food through which the equivalent of the 1 per cent levy from off-course bookmakers could be directed to the racing board. This Bill does not allow us to sort out that aspect.

This is not a political issue and there is support on all side of the House for the case that we have to invest on a regular basis in our racecourses. There is hardly a man or woman who does not have an interest in horses. They need not be racehorse owners or trainers. They need not even be regular attenders at race meetings. Everybody up and down the country, from the housing estate to the large house, has a love of the horse. There is a huge number who never attend race meetings but who daily, certainly weekly, attend their local bookmaker. The case could be made that Irish racing is not the only raw material for the off-course bookmaker but so far as we are concerned the racing industry backed up by the bloodstock industry is a most important industry both as an employer and tourist attraction. I must acknowledge that £500,000 has been given this year by way of the Estimate for the Department of Agriculture and Food to Fairyhouse racecourse. An equivalent amount was given last year but I am sure the Minister would agree that we need to put on a regular footing the investment in our racecourses throughout the country.

Our domestic racing industry is a developing one but it needs finance to develop to its full potential. We need action now to preserve the valuable employment in the industry. Over 25,000 people are employed, both directly and indirectly, in the racing industry. We need investment to secure the long term future of the bloodstock industry. The Minister is aware that a weak racing industry has implications for all of the other aspects of the bloodstock industry, an industry which has the potential to contribute even more significantly to our economy in the years to come if a means is provided, as I have suggested, through which the domestic racing industry can develop racecourse facilities and prize money improved and the long term employment of those in the industry secured.

The reduction in the rate of off-course betting tax to 7.5 per cent would also make bets in Ireland a more attractive proposition for overseas punters, particularly those in the United Kingdom where the present rate is also 10 per cent. The United Kingdom credit betting market is estimated at approximately £500 million sterling per annum. This is a most responsive market to differential tax rates between betting markets. For every 1 per cent of the UK credit betting market attracted to Ireland by a more favourable taxation regime here, domestic betting turnover would increase by IR£6 million approximately per annum.

The Minister will be aware of the significant implications in my amendment for the Financial Services Centre and the credit betting market, particularly in relation to attracting companies from the UK. The terms of the amendment can be implemented at minimal cost to the Exchequer and widespread benefits will flow over a short space of time. Now is the opportunity to secure the future of the domestic bloodstock industry for the nineties and I urge the Minister to seize it by accepting the amendment.

The Minister's advisers and officials in the Department of Finance, react strongly the moment they hear the expression “a self-financing tax cut”. I do not think they believe that such a cut exists. They have heard arguments made over the years about self-financing tax cuts in different areas. It is important to put on record the fact that Deputy Dukes, as Minister for Finance, in 1985 reduced off-course betting tax from 20 per cent to 10 per cent and that within a few years revenue from that tax had more than doubled. I accept that there is a limit to self-financing tax cuts, but with the potential of attracting considerable sums of money from overseas punters, particularly from the UK and with the potential for the Financial Services Centre of credit punting, the time is right for us to make this move. That should have been done in 1985 but we should make this one final move to reduce the rate of off-course betting tax from 10 per cent to 7½ per cent and impose a levy of 1 per cent on off-course bookmakers.

The Minister should direct the equivalent of that 1 per cent through a sub-head in the Estimates for the Department of Agriculture and Food to the Irish Racing Board towards the improvement of facilities at our race courses and increasing prize money. We should be in a position to reward the owners, breeders and trainers of our bloodstock industry, all of whom we depend on for that sport.
Many of us get hours of pleasure from that sport. One does not have to be an owner, a trainer or a jockey to enjoy that sport which is provided by investments by others at great cost to themselves.

We have suggested a commencement date of 1 January 1990 so that there will be no loss of revenue between now and that date. We are suggesting that a tax rate of 10 per cent should remain until next January to allow the Minister an opportunity to include in the Estimates for the Department of Agriculture a new subhead for the equivalent of 1 per cent to be directed to the Irish Racing Board. I would like to have been able to table an amendment suggesting that a 1 per cent levy be imposed on bookmakers but it is not up to me to do that. Had I taken that route, and my amendment was ruled out of order, I would have been precluded from expressing my views and developing the discussion.

The Minister may need time to consider how he can put the three steps in place. What we do today in relation to the reduction from 10 per cent to 7½ per cent is the first step. We then, through the Government offices, have to get the 1 per cent levy in place. I suggest to the Minister that between now and Report Stage he make arrangements to have that included in the Bill. The third step is to adjust the Estimate for the Department of Agriculture, which is presented in the autumn, to allow the proceeds of that levy to be passed on to the Irish Racing Board. If we agree in principle with what I am suggesting, and I hope the Minister will do so, we must take action now in regard to the first step in the Finance Bill. The third step involves a change in the Estimates, and if the Minister was to suggest that the matter be left over we would be postponing the implementation of my suggestion for 18 months. As it is, there will be an eight months delay but if we do not move now to put the pieces in place for the Estimates in the autumn it will be January 12 months before we will be in a position to direct money on a regular basis to the Irish Racing Board.

Off-course betting revenue is worth £22 million to the Exchequer. I would be happy if the Minister included a clause in the Finance Bill to the effect that the first £22 million of off-course betting tax at the 7½ per cent rate should continue to go to the Exchequer and that the 1 per cent I am suggesting should be collected on sums over and above that figure. My point is that the Exchequer should not be without at least £22 million, the amount they collect at present. I do not want to reduce the direct Exchequer take from off-course betting. We want to guarantee that amount and, hopefully, by an increase in the value of betting turnover due to a reduction in the off-course betting tax and the attraction of overseas punters, particularly from the United Kingdom we will have about £2 million or 1 per cent, to go directly to the Irish Racing Board.

I feel strongly about this matter. The Government should seize this opportunity to put my suggestion into operation. We have had reports from the Commission on Taxation on this issue and it was dealt with by the Killanin Commission. Indeed, my suggestion is in line with the recommendations of that report. I understand that it suggested a reduction to 8 per cent of the off-course betting tax and the imposition of a 2 per cent levy. I am suggesting that it should be 7½ per cent and 1 per cent to keep a differential between us and the UK rate and to maximise the possibility of attracting credit punting to the Financial Services Centre.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: I should like to support the amendment tabled by my colleague. There is a great deal of misunderstanding about the bloodstock industry and the racing scene here. Some people regard it as the sport of kings and are of the opinion that a lot of money is being made by a few individuals. Those people hold the view that suggestions like that put forward by Deputy Doyle are for the purpose of putting more money into the pockets of a few people. That is far from the truth.

MainHeading.P: The Minister will be aware of the condition of many of our race tracks. They are a disgrace to any sport and could not be classified as public places of entertainment. Many of them do not have such basic facilities as toilets. Very little money has been spent on racecourses to try to attract spectators to that sport. What is badly needed is a regular flow of funds to the Irish Racing Board to enable them to prepare a long-term development programme for racecourses. They should be in a position to provide facilities that will attract more people to race meetings. I am sure the Irish Racing Board will be given permission to bOrrow money to accelerate any development programme. If the Minister listened to me I might be able to persuade him to accept my views.

Speaker.P: I am listening to the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: If money was given to the Irish Racing Board for a development programme the Exchequer would benefit in the long run. Employment would be created and the Exchequer would benefit through PAYE, PRSI and VAT paid on materials. The Exchequer will receive a fair slice in return for any investment. At the same time racing facilities will be modernised and more people will be attracted to races. Ireland is regarded as the home of the horse and the bloodstock industry is a very big one. It used to be a show piece for this country. We spend vast sums of money in advertising this country so as to attract tourists here, and horses were a vehicle by which this country became famous throughout the world. The condition of our half bred industry at present leaves an awful lot to be desired. Those who follow racing only have to look at the results at the main festival meetings abroad to see that this year we did not even have one winner at the Cheltenham festival.
Irish bred horses.
Irish trained horses.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: We are advertising the Irish racing industry so that people will come here to look for horses so as to help that industry from an export point of view. The reality is that we did not have a winner this year at Cheltenham. How long is it since we have had a classic winner in Britain?

The writing is on the wall and the reality of the situation, for those who may not be fully aware of the value of this industry, is that, as Deputy Doyle pointed out, 25,000 people are either directly or indirectly employed in this industry in this country. I should like to invite any Member of this House to visit a few of these stud farms in rural parts of Ireland. Deputy Davern knows one of these stud farms in particular, Coolmore Stud, which employs about 500 people in the middle of rural Ireland. I ask the Minister how much it would cost the industry to attract a foreign industry into this country which would give jobs to 500 people. I am talking about highly skilled people who have a natural affinity towards horses, who can use their skills very quickly abroad and who would have absolutely no trouble whatsoever in finding employment in other countries. Five hundred jobs are being provided by one stud farm in County Tipperary.

We have to find a way of making certain that we have the facilities so that people will go to watch racing and that we have prize money which will make it attractive for people to continue to invest in the industry and put horses into training so that they will get reasonable rewards if their horses win particular races. At present the prize money for races, particularly those run on the flat is deplorable and we have to find some way of attracting more money into prize money. This will attract people to put their horses into training which again will give employment in training establishments and race tracks, for example, through the employment of jockeys and grooms, and in all the other ancillary service attached to that industry.

MainHeading.P: It is not a question of coming in here with a special plea for a very small group of people. We should be very wary that if this industry continues the way it is going it will get into serious difficulties. The world is becoming a very small place and already some of out top stallions are being sent to Australia for certain periods of the year. The Australian Government decided in their wisdom to reduce off-course betting and to channel money on a regular basis into racing purely from the point of view of creating employment and keeping the industry going. The bloodstock industry in Australia is now booming, and it is booming under a Socialist Government — a Government who saw that it was advisable to put something back into racing so as to protect and develop that industry. If we sit here nice and snugly and think this industry will continue the way it has been going we might have reason to have second thoughts about it. People can shift their investment from this country very quickly into places like Australia where it is more attractive to breed horses because the prize money for those who eventually race the horses which are bred from these top sires is more attractive. In the space of a couple of years the bloodstock industry in this country could be wiped out.

Whatever revenue the Exchequer is getting at present from off-course betting, PAYE, PRSI and all the other taxes I have spoken about before could very quickly disappear and for that reason I appeal to the House to support the amendment proposed by my colleague, Deputy Avril Doyle. We are not asking the taxpayers of this country to fund anything; we are putting forward a formula which in itself, by reducing off-course betting, should increase the turnover. This in turn would produce greater profit for bookmakers and rather than bookmakers getting all of the profit we would impose a 1 per cent levy which would go to the Racing Board who, therefore, would have a regular flow of funds. We are not asking the taxpayers to fund investment into the pockets of a few people. We are asking this House to wake up and realise that the Irish bloodstock industry is declining, that the racing industry is in jeopardy, that a number of horse trainers are finding it more and more difficult to keep going——

Speaker.P: And a number of punters too.
When the Deputy gets advice he will not take it; that is his problem.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: That is another day's work, The age groups attending race meetings need to be watched. Younger people are not coming through as in the past and an older population than before are now attending races. Now is the time to look at this industry and produce some radical measure which will arrest the decline of this industry and enable it to advance and create more employment.

It should be put clearly on the record that we are not asking the taxpayers of this country to fund prize money or facilities at race tracks. When the present leader of Fine Gael, Deputy Alan Dukes, reduced the tax from 20 per cent down to 10 per cent that generated more turnover and it more than compensated in the longer term for the loss or revenue in the short term. By reducing off-course betting to 7½ per cent our rate would be below that in Britain. We are in the EC and there is no reason why English money should not be coming in here to Irish bookmakers. That in itself would create a greater turnover and the racing board would get their funds through the 1 per cent levy.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Doyle was quite specific when she said that we are not asking the Department of Finance to forego any loss in revenue. If we want to impose the condition she suggested whereby the present take is £22 million and that £22 million must still be got I am confident this could be done very quickly. I am asking the House to realise that the future of this industry is not too rosy. I want to put it on the record that the advances being made in places like Australia are a very stern note of warning to us that our bloodstock industry could be seriously affected if money moves from this country down to Australia and the top sires move with that money. We have something very special and we should hold on to it.

Deputy Davern was right when he spoke about the number of winners at Cheltenham and other top race meetings in Britain being Irish bred. That is not the point. The point is that, as a nation, we are not seen to be the leading country in racing that we were and which has had a serious effect on this industry. We should not ignore the fact that there are at stake here 25,000 jobs. Anybody who takes any interest in racing or has any contact with horse trainers will know that very few of them are making any sort of a decent living here at present. Some of them have owners but find it very difficult to receive payment. If one must incur anything up to £5,000 or £6,000 to keep a horse in training and receive prize money of £1,000 only for winning a race, that is not a great return.

We must remember that there are many people in this country who have kept horses who have never won a race. Bearing in mind prize money of £1,000 when weighted against an investment of, say, anything between £100,000 and £1 million, in addition to the upkeep on the horse, where is one going to go? Inevitably one will go to wherever the prize money is greater. People who traditionally invested an awful lot of money in bloodstock in this country are now moving their investment to places like Australia where bigger prize money is the main attraction. If that continues to happen the breeding industry will encounter very serious difficulties.

I do not want to make a political point of this. I am aware that the Minister has a deep personal knowledge of the industry. I am satisfied that he has the good will to recognise that it is an important industry with tremendous potential, that all we must do is, first, recognise the problem and, second, find a solution to it in the short term that will not cost the Exchequer anything.

I appeal to the Minister and to all sides of the House to pay attention to the points made in the course of this debate. I recognise that, in a period of cutbacks, it is difficult to justify taking decisions which may be misinterpreted. However, this is a time to demonstrate some little courage in this respect. It is also a time when those of us interested in maintaining employment in that industry should be able to respond to any type of ill-informed criticism of what we are endeavouring to do here. I repeat, it is not a question of trying to put money into the hands of a few. Rather is it an endeavour to create employment in an industry which is very important to this country and to maintain an industry for which many people had to struggle hard in the first place.

We should be mindful of the fact that we might wake up when it is too late, when all the top investors and best stallions will have left the country, ending up in Australia or elsewhere. We have a glorious opportunity here to develop this industry if only we have the courage to take the steps proposed in this amendment.

Speaker.P: It had not been my intention to speak but I should like to voice my support for the industry here. If we examine the State of Nevada tax laws we find that when their rates were reduced from 20 per cent to 10 per cent their income trebled, that when they reduced the rate further to 1 per cent the yield rose to over five times what it had been previously. I appreciate very much what Deputy Dukes did as Minister for Finance in 1985. He increased the yield from betting; that is the incentive to get people to pay tax on betting. It is bad enough to take a chance on losing one's money but to pay tax before losing it is even worse. It is like the pint after hours; it is one of those irresistible temptations.

MainHeading.P: I agree with other speakers that the facilities available at race courses have become diabolical. We must remember the enjoyment people gain there but the main drawback is that the prize money is not sufficient. Whatever about flat racing, particularly in the national hunt, the prize money is simply not a sufficient return on the risk being taken. Of every 100 horses born, 30 will be found to be unsuitable; more than likely no more than 10 per cent of the remainder will ever see a race course and, of the 10 per cent, 1 per cent only will ever win enough races to justify their existence. Therefore, it will be seen that there is a major problem in that area.

I might put this question to the Minister: with the way things are going, will there be an Irish betting office left here because they are being continually taken over by British bookmakers? While it might add weight to Deputy Doyle's argument to say that foreign companies could use their offices elsewhere to transfer a bet to Ireland, I am concerned about the indigenous industry that is losing out and unable to compete. My fear is that betting will become a cartel, that there will no longer be a real chance of an outside swipe at something somewhere along the line, that it will become a fixed market, so controlled that there will no longer be any real interest in betting. Deputy McGahon and I were in India recently and we were extended the courtesy of paying a visit to a racecourse there where, with small money, they slashed the price in two and, of course, Deputy McGahon would not follow my instructions.

I am extremely worried that there will not be an Irish bookmaker remaining here. I accept that under EC regulations other companies are perfectly entitled to come here but I contend there should be a reduced form of taxation for the indigenous industry — which has proved successful already — and in particular for those who support race meetings. They afford such a sense of enjoyment. I suppose one could say it is part of what we are ourselves. If more was reinvested from increased betting moneys in prize money and facilities we would be talking about a much improved scene. If the Minister looks at the increase in registered bets since 1985 he will appreciate that if there were more still there would be even greater registration and all of us would be much happier about the honesty and integrity of racing.

Speaker.P: This is a subject in which I have had a life long interest. Indeed, perhaps I know more about it than I should. In supporting this amendment I want to express my appreciation of the Irish bloodstock industry. Equally I want the Minister to acknowledge the prominence of the Irish horse and everybody connected with it worldwide. I had the privilege and pleasure recently of attending a race meeting in Bombay with Deputy Davern and nothing changes, whether it be in Leopardstown or Bombay. We were losers. However, we were left in no doubt about the esteem in which the Irish horse is held worldwide.
What about the Irish TD?

I do not know about that. I suppose the essential thing is that he has the respect of those in his constituency. Neither were we left in any doubt about the esteem in which Irish jockeys are held worldwide, in particular in Bombay where Michael Kinane leads the field every winter.

No Irish Government have ever appreciated or done sufficient to bolster our racing industry which is clearly needed at present. Anybody who has followed the successes of Irish horses over the past 20 years will have been saddened to note the dearth of winners in recent years at Cheltenham. Indeed, the steady supply of classic winners turned out here in the seventies and early eighties has ground to a halt, indicating that the Irish bloodstock industry is ailing for the reasons Deputy Seán Barrett has advanced — that the temptations and attractions of selling a good animal are overwhelming. God knows, we do not lead the world in many things but we were a world leader in horses. Now Irish horses of ability and promise are being sold for more glamorous racing in England and France. The attraction is the huge difference in the stakes.

MainHeading.P: At this stage I should like to pay homage — and take some of the credit — to my celebrated colleague, Deputy McCreevy, who had the courage in 1984 to say on television — and I supported him — that we did not pay the betting tax. I was sent to Coventry by some of my more self-righteous colleagues in this House, it was terrible for a person to admit that he had not paid the betting tax. One million people in the real world outside these four walls knew I and Deputy McCreevy were telling the truth. There is a real world outside these portals and Deputy Dukes recognised that and took steps and reduced the betting tax from the penal imposition of 20 per cent, which was obscene, to 10 per cent. As Deputy Davern has already stated, the Exchequer benefited enormously.

I have no difficulty in paying the betting tax as it is now because it is reasonable. I think most bookmakers have worked with the Revenue Commissioners in gathering that tax. At this stage I want to say that I agree with Deputy Davern who warned us of the growth and the influence of English bookmakers in Ireland. That is a worrying trend because these big combines are squeezing out the independent Irish bookmakers. They are doing it in a very subtle way. They are paying the tax for the punter. They are putting undue pressure on the small, independent Irish bookmaker who cannot compete. In order to survive that is driving him to under the counter betting. That is very subtle and it is definitely unfair competition. I view with concern the increasing influence of British bookmaking concerns in this country. It is not good for this country, it is not good for the punter and it is not good for the bloodstock industry as a whole. I would ask the Minister to look at that problem with a very keen eye.

Deputy Barrett referred to the need to boost and help the racing industry. There is no doubt that that is needed, particularly for many country courses. The value of races in some cases is as low as £800 for the winner and that is totally unrealistic. That is one of the reasons there is a question mark over Irish racing. I am referring to the correctness of racing. As a punter I have grave reservations about the correctness of Irish racing. I understand that an owner is not paying a trainer for the punter's benefit, he is paying him for his own benefit.

Some of the Irish racing results make me raise my eyebrows because horses can be put away — and the Minister knows what I mean by that — for periods of up to one or two years and then sprung, and the unfortunate punter is left looking in sheer disbelief at the form book. John Comyn in the Irish Independent continually highlights reversals of form that are mind boggling.

Speaker.P: They do not all win.
The Holy Ghost sometimes does not know what is happening in Irish racing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Charlie must have been away for two years. There was a fair reversal of form there.
I would support the amendment——
——but I think Irish racing needs a face lift and a spring cleaning from the punters point of view.

There is a need to update the Betting Act. There should be a charter for the punters because bookmakers can write their own rules. Some bookies are paying first past the post, some are paying on the official result, some have their limits, there is a free for all in that area. There should be hard and fast rules which apply to everybody. The Minister should have discussions with the National Bookmaker's Association to work out a fair deal for both the punter and the bookmaker.
In conclusion, I support this amendment. I agree with the proposal that 1 per cent be given back to the Irish industry. I would ask the Minister to reduce the overall tax a little further.
I am not one of the racing fraternity but I know something about betting duty.

MainHeading.P: (Interruptions.)

Speaker.P: The situation in relation to betting duty undoubtedly is one where the Department of Finance and Customs and Excise live in a different world, as Deputy McGahon said. In another capacity I was privileged to see how the law enforcement operation worked in relation to betting duty in the days of the 20 per cent duty. At that time I spoke to Customs and Excise officers very frequently in the course of conducting prosecutions, and they all told me that at 20 per cent they were just wasting their time, that so much money was being lost to the Exchequer which would never be recovered and that the whole situation was foolish. When the rate was reduced to 10 per cent the result was entirely predictable that there would be a boost in the yield.

I believe there is still a huge amount of money being lost to the Exchequer. The one place where it is obviously being lost to the Exchequer is by telephone betting. I do not believe any of that carries any tax. I understand the poor old Customs and Excise people could not get a warrant to tap a phone if they were paid double for it. Unless bookies actually see themselves at risk on telephone betting, they will continue to do a lot of heavy betting off their books.
They are being booked.

They are not being booked out; let us be realistic about it, they are being booked on the back of cigarette boxes. The simple fact is that the volume of betting will yield far more than at present if the tax is reduced further so that it will not make it worth any bookmakers' time not to book a bet in his office — and that includes a telephone bet. The bookmakers will not like what I am about to say. You must use telephone tapping and take one or two as examples, and that would stop also. If you stopped telephone betting being off the books, I think the yield from betting duty would be increased by 50 per cent.

MainHeading.P: I agree with what Deputy McGahon said about the Betting Act, 1931. It is a joke. It is a puritanical thing with all sorts of regulations about not having inducements to go into betting shops; it is almost as if they were something between a morgue and a public loo, or like a brothel which cannot even be decorated. It is the most absurd idea. The other point made by Deputy McGahon is correct, that is, that the behaviour of bookies is really a matter for themselves. The method of enforcing standards among bookmakers, which is the Garda Superintendent witholding consent of the licence, that is archaic. I have recently seen one or two court examples of how draft that can be in its own way. It would be far better if there was a charter of implied rights for every punter who would know what he was taking on and he would not have to look to his local superintendent to get him fair play from the bookmakers.

In relation to the English betting offices I should like to say two things. I think Deputy Doyle's point is right; if there is a significant differential in the tax treatment of Irish betting from English betting then the presence of those offices may bring more money into this country. I do not believe the employment offered by them is going to be very significantly less than the employment offered by other bookmakers. The capital they are bringing in to their end of the business — which is very substantial indeed in terms of the equipment and the telecommunications equipment — would not have happened if we were waiting for the Irish bookmaking business to do it. Therefore, we cannot afford to be too hostile to them. They are coming in and investing their capital. They are so big that they cannot afford to be caught cheating, because if they are caught cheating and are deprived of their licences the consequences of them would be a multi-million pound loss. For a Joe Soap running a small office in the middle of nowhere on a wing and a prayer, the risk to his own capital is far less. I would not be too hostile to English bookmakers coming in here — although I know there are others who would take a different view — if they are bringing in good business. It is about time the Irish bookmakers got their act together and started to compete rather than whingeing about the money the English bookmakers are bringing in.

I take the point made by Deputy Davern that the competition in relation to offering to pay the tax is unfair. It must be unfair because, effectively it means that they are subsidising the odds by the amount of the tax they are giving. It is all the more unfair the higher the amount of tax. This is another reason for reducing the 10 per cent rate to 7½ per cent — I would go as far as 5 per cent. It might become a little ridiculous if it were less than 5 per cent. If the Minister brings it down to 5 per cent, in two years time he will have more money out of racing. If he does something about the telephone betting he will get more money out of racing and if he does something about the betting Act he will improve his situation, also.

Deputy Doyle is correct when she says that this set of proposals would be self-financing. All the experience from the past is that the Department of Finance and the Revenue Commissioners have underestimated the volume of betting that is going on in the country. By overtaxing they have driven betting underground. If a few punters were consulted on how betting should be taxed, a lot more money would be got out of it. If the Minister listened to the Deputies involved he would realise that they are telling him what to do with it. I am glad to see that there is a consensus in this House.

Speaker.P: I did not know that Charlie was offering, but I bow to him. He has been in the winners enclosure more often than I.

I would like to add my voice in support of having something done about the whole racing industry. To put the matter on a serious note, there are thousands of people employed as a result of racing, owning horses, etc. In my constituency the numbers employed in breeding, racing stables and all other ancillary occupations would add up to thousands employed in that industry.

A few basic principles should be understood before you tackle any problem. From going racing I knew the Minister for Finance long before he came into this House. I know that he understands, as does Deputy McGahon, the twilight world in which we all exist who have anything to do with racing and gambling. Many years ago when the price of land reached enormous proportions I realised that the day would come when things would have to change. There is an economic value on everything and when the price of land reached an extraordinary price per acre, it then went the other way. People found that they could not make an economic return on the price they were paying. You can apply the same principle to the owning of a horse. Over the past ten or 15 years the fundamental principle of what owning horses was about was forgotten. It became so important to concentrate on the breeding of horses that horses became too important to race. It would be too much of a chance to take the horse to the races because he could be beaten by another racehorse and the value to the syndicate would go down. When the top of the stallion market started going the other way, it emphasised that basic principle.

MainHeading.P: It all relates back to the value of land or the economic principle involved. People come to see one horse compete against another and one horse beating another. That is what stakes races are about. People say they have a better horse and they make a wager of £100, or whatever. That principle was forgotten in relation to the stallion industry. People come to the track to see one horse beating another and this generates money for those who build the stands and for the racecourse owners. There is also the money that comes to fund racing by the take-off from the betting tax. Irish racing is funded solely by the course betting tax. The traditional argument about taking any slice off the off-course betting and putting it into racing has been put like this: most money bet in the SP offices is bet on English racing, etc. so why should the off-course punter fund Irish racing?

That brings me to the point about which Deputy McGahon was speaking. The reason for the off-course punter not betting on Irish races is that he does not think he is getting fair play or that the form works out as well as it does in English racing. Why is that? I will tell the House the basic reason and I speak from no little experience in this matter. Somebody decides that he would like to have a national hunt horse, because most Irish people like to go to see national hunt racing. His base is, say, £10,000 on a three year old horse, or whatever, which will not run until he is four years old. He is put into training and will cost another £6,000 to be kept for that year. He stands at £16,000 then, or probably would stand at £20,000 between the Turf Club and everything else. He is run in the bumper race in Naas, or wherever the case may be, where the first prize will be about £1,000. Out of that will have to come 20 per cent for the trainer. I presume it is ridden by an amateur so 20 per cent for the jockey will not be taken out. You would get back about £700 for winning a very competitive race, which is exactly one month's grain. A horse at the top echelon of national hunt racing would have to win some very great Irish races to pay for his keep in any one year.

The only chance that an ordinary fellow has who is racing horses is to gamble. I have owned race horses and owned shares in them for many, many years. I am prepared to admit that every horse that I ever owned did not always win on his or her merits on any particular day. Without the gamble, the horse stands at £20,000 and you will come home with one month's training fees. Everyone is in it for the sport, but you like to get a reasonable return for your money, or have the expectation of getting it. You will punt that horse on the particular day that you want to.

Perhaps the off-course punter is right. There is much codology talked about racing, that every horse is not trying and so on. Having owned horses down through the years, I know that the day that they are off form there is a difference of about two or three lengths. They probably cannot go any more quickly. However, people must have an opportunity to get some return on their investment. They will not come to the race meeting unless they are going to see competitive racing and they will not see competitive racing unless the prize money is realistic. That is the fundamental problem with Irish racing. At any mid-week meeting here in the middle of the summer there are very few paying customers. Therefore, you have to increase stake money to make racing competitive. By that means you bring more people to the race meetings and generate more revenue from the betting levy or the tax, which will increase the take. You must put an injection into it at some stage to start the ball rolling.

When my mother used to walk to Nass or to the Curragh and see new stands, she used to say that she built those stands with her pounds going in. I attended the Curragh races when it cost two shillings to get into the stand and it was the same in Naas. That is going back a long, long time. The ordinary Joe Soap goes in to have his £1 or £2 bet. It is not, with all due respect, the Robert Sangsters or the Vincent O'Briens who keep racing going here. It is the ordinary Joe Soaps all around the country.

Another thing wrong with Irish racing is that the bulk of the prize money from sponsors and so on goes into flat racing where the bigger returns are for syndication etc. The real chance of big money is there but the majority of people who own horses own at national hunt level and it is the betting at national hunt level that funds the whole of racing. I have never seen the figures, nor have they been published, of what the take off is in a year of national hunt racing as against flat racing, but the serious punting goes on in national hunt racing, yet the funding goes into the racing board for the flat end of it for which the rewards are greater. It is necessary that the rewards be great for flat racing for breeding etc., but there is an anomaly there. At some stage some Minister for Finance will have to inject money into the system to bring up the level.

Speaker.hpid: Acting Chairman (Mr. S. Walsh) Acting Chairman (Mr. S. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Let me remind the House that Part II of this Bill is expected to be brought to a conclusion at 7 p.m.

I agree with Deputy Doyle and in principle the Minister might agree too, about total off course betting taxes and the one big pool for the whole funding of racing. Ministers for Finance and Governments have an objection to this, but racing is in a crisis. It has been a hobby of mine all my life. Some Minister for Finance at some stage will have to take his courage in his hands and say, “Here is X amount of money”. When it comes to reducing off course tax as is being advocated now and putting some of that into racing or the funding coming directly from an Exchequer fund, I say to whatever Minister will be doing it, it will be a waste of time giving it, say, to the Racing Board if it is not given under strict conditions. If extra money is pumped into racing I do not want to see it channelled into flat racing. There are enough sponsors out there willing to fund flat racing. It must come at the other end of the scale. The punter will not attend unless it is competitive racing and there will not be competitive racing unless the fellow owning the horse thinks he has a realistic chance of getting back his money, and unless someone is prepared to stop the cycle there will be no end to this. It is not economic to keep a race horse in training. I hope the Minister at some stage can take these matters on board. I could talk for a long time on this. There are other things I could say. I think it is not realised that one thing is linked into the other, someone has to use courage and break the circle.
One point——
I was wondering if the House wished to hear the Minister.
They do not want to hear me.

Deputy Doyle referred to attracting English money and English punters over. In recent years the Racing Board had the initiative to initiate Sunday racing which has being a huge success all over Ireland. To continue in that vein, many English punters fly over, and that gives us an ideal opportunity to relieve them of some badly needed cash.

I urge on the Minister the wisdom of accepting this amendment. The advice he is getting here is of the best. We have had impartial, by-partisan advice from Kildare, the home of the racing industry, we have had advice from punters in Louth, from Dublin SouthEast and some from Wexford where they are not too bad at it either and from Tipperary where they are beginning to catch up with the rest of us in the business. I would like to add one more thing. I think I can advise the Minister on this as the only former holder of the office he now has who went through the experience of reducing the tax on betting and who saw the effects of it. I confess I was very sceptical starting out on the exercise but I am very glad I overcame that scepticism and did the job, because it worked out. Within 18 months the effects had worked their way through the system and the revenue had increased.

The amendment sets out to do a couple of other things, some of which cannot be included in the amendment. One has to do with getting funding into the industry. A good deal has been said about that. It needs to be injected into the industry, not just enterprise money and not just into facilities on tracks. They are both extremely important, but for the great majority of breeders there needs to be a way in which the rewards can be accelerated or increased because that is going to be a very important part of keeping our industry healthy. For those reasons we are pushing this amendment. The experience shows that something of this kind can work, and I urge the Minister to accept the amendment.

I would not have time to take on board all the suggestions and arguments made here. Like Deputy Dukes and Deputy McCreevy, I suppose I was unfortunate enough in that the first job I had was down in Kildare very close to the Curragh and that is where I developed——
Bad habits.
Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Speaker.P: He was a happy man in those days.

I am still a happy man. I recognise the contribution Irish racing has made and will continue to make to this economy. I recognise the thousands of jobs that have been created by the industry with no assistance from the State, good, bad or indifferent. It is an industry that is synonymous with our country abroad. Not alone are there problems on the racing side, there are problems on the show jumping side; there is a range of problems. As Deputy McCreevy said tonight, throwing money at it is not going to solve all the problems of the horse industry. I appreciate fully the contribution it makes and the problems there. I have done a certain amount of work on this.

MainHeading.P: This amendment came in only last night — I am not blaming the Deputy for that. I am prepared to look at it and the various aspects of it, but I cannot in all honesty say here tonight I will accept this amendment as it is and then talk about committing the Government next January without the Government even having sat down while we decide here we are going to spend X amount of somebody's Estimate in such a way. I could not buy that at this stage. In case Deputies think it is all one way traffic, it is not. I admired Deputy Dukes at the time he referred to. I thought 20 per cent was penal. It did not work out quite as well as people think around here, nevertheless it improved significantly. The decision was the right one at the time because evasion was horrific. The year was 1985. In 1984 with £102 million turnover the tax take was £20.5 million. In 1985 it was down to £16 million, in 1986 up to £18.3 million, in 1987 £19.5 million, correspondingly because 10 per cent turnover was taken, in 1988 with £224 million turnover the figure was £22.4 million. It cannot be said it was self-financing. Deputy Doyle made the point that it is self-financing, but it is not. How much evasion or anything else takes place we will never know.

I cannot accept the amendment as it stands this evening. Maybe the Deputy wants to say a few words more about it. I am prepared to look at it. I recognise the problems. I do not see the passing of this amendment this evening as a simple solution and I am not prepared to go along that road tonight.

The problem has been highlighted here by two Deputies already. I want to give notice that I will be bringing forward a further amendment on Report Stage the purpose of which will be to make illegal the practice of so-called tax rebating offered as an inducement by a number of off course bookmakers. The amendment I intend to bring forward will impose a legal obligation on all off course bookmakers not to accept a bet unless an amount equivalent to the amount of betting duty due in respect of that bet is paid to the bookmaker by the punter. That is an attempt to restore a level playing field between the Irish indigenous industry and the outsiders who come in. This is just to give notice for Report Stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): I thank the Minister for his brief reply. I understand he is going to consider our amendment between now and Report Stage.

I would not promise to have a resolution by Report Stage which is to be taken next Tuesday. Much work is still to be done on this. It is too big a problem. I would not like to throw a simplistic answer at it but I recognise it is there and we can have more discussion on it.

It is three years since the Killanin Commission suggested this and for two of those the Minister's party have been in Government. I urge him please to bring it to Government before the weekend and come back to us on Report Stage on the matter. He knows he has support within his Cabinet.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Could we have some discussion?

There are a number of unanswered questions in relation to the whole situation and it is not the way to run any business or Government just to take a clip decision like that. The amendment proposes to take 2½ per cent off. I have had suggestions from the racing industry not to take 2½ per cent but to take 1½ per cent. Other people suggest other figures. There are a number of areas there which are not going to be resolved by next Tuesday.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Would the Minister agree to some bilateral discussions between now and Report Stage?
We will have further discussions on it and tease it out and see what we can do.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): With this side of the House?
Yes.

Whether we reduce the amount from 10 per cent to 8½ per cent or from 10 per cent to 7½ per cent plus a 1 per cent levy is, perhaps, academic. We are trying to get the equivalent of 1 per cent of the revenue to the Irish Racing Board to improve facilities and stakes, for the reasons Members on all sides of the House have indicated. I urge the Minister to consider it.
That will not solve the problems of the racing industry on its own.

On its own it will not, but it will go a very long way, as the Australian experience has shown. Other countries also operate their racing industry this way. We will have no bloodstock industry unless we do something urgently.
I have as much appreciation of the bloodstock industry as anybody else in this House, but I will not make silly decisions this evening.
Am I in order in re-entering the amendment on Report Stage?
Yes.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

As it is now 7 o'clock I am required to put the following question in accordance with the Order of the Dáil of yesterday: “That the sections undisposed of in Part II of the Bill are hereby agreed to”.
Question put and agreed to.
